pageContext.claim: “But the big announcement is in Lordstown, Ohio, they're going to be selling that plant to Workhorse, it's called -- they make electric trucks because the enemy...They kept telling me with Lordstown, because General Motors closed it while they did the right thing, they sold it to a company. That's going to do a great job with that beautiful plant, and that happened just a little while ago, just a little while ago. They'll be spending a lot of money on fixing it up. It's subject to the UAW. They've got to get out there make a deal. UAW, come on, got to make a deal. But that's a great thing, right? Because that was the only thing they could hit me with. They couldn't have been happy with anything, because we've been so good, but this is -- what about Lordstown? What about Lordstown? I call up Mary Barra, 'Will you make a deal or open it, please. I'm getting killed with that plant.' Anyway, today she called, they're going to be opening, it's going to be a great company going there, it is really wonderful. And another historic action.”
pageContext.analysis: GM has only said it is in discussions to sell the Lordstown complex to Workhorse, but no deal had been concluded at the time held this rally. It's unclear how many workers will retain their jobs. "Workhorse, a small company based near Cincinnati, makes battery-powered pickup trucks, delivery vans, drones and aircraft, faces big obstacles in getting the Lordstown plant humming again with hundreds working the line," the New York Times noted. "It has no experience in mass vehicle production, its shares recently traded for less than $1, and quarterly revenues were less than the price of one high-end sports car." Workhorse employs fewer than 100 people, compared with the thousands who worked for G.M. in Lordstown as recently as April 2018.
